channel.title: NYT > Books
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Books of The Times: ‘The New Book of Snobs’ Updates the Shifting Science of Social Cues
item.description: D.J. Taylor’s clever and timely work contends that the world would be a poorer place without a bit of insolence and ostentation.
item.dc:creator: DWIGHT GARNER
item.category: The New Book of Snobs: A Definitive Guide to Modern Snobbery (Book)

item.title: Books of The Times: ‘Shattered’ Charts Hillary Clinton’s Course Into the Iceberg
item.description: Jonathan Allen and Amie Parnes’s account of the 2016 presidential election depicts a dysfunctional Clinton campaign and the many mistakes it made.
item.dc:creator: MICHIKO KAKUTANI
item.category: Shattered: Inside Hillary Clinton's Doomed Campaign (Book)

item.title: Nonfiction: Elizabeth Warren Lays Out the Reasons Democrats Should Keep Fighting
item.description: In “This Fight Is Our Fight,” Elizabeth Warren offers a manifesto for the Democratic resistance to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: PAUL KRUGMAN
item.category: This Fight Is Our Fight: The Battle to Save Americas Middle Class (Book)

item.title: Nonfiction: Bush Nostalgia Is Overrated, but His Book of Paintings Is Not
item.media:description: Sgt. First Class Michael R. Rodriguez, U.S. Army.
item.description: The work in George W. Bush’s “Portraits of Courage” reveals a surprisingly adept artist who has dramatically improved his technique while also doing penance for a great disaster of American history.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN ALTER
item.category: Portraits of Courage: A Commander in Chief's Tribute to America's Warriors (Book)

item.title: Match Book: Mom Seeks Novel for Family Book Club, No Kafka or Y.A. Allowed
item.description: In this installment of Match Book, a woman seeks a work of fiction that will unite her “disparate group of avid readers,” also known as her children.
item.dc:creator: NICOLE LAMY

item.title: Q. & A.: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Stephen Tobolowsky’s ‘My Adventures With God’
item.description: The actor talks about his new book, which details his “always-changing, ever-fascinating” relationship to spirituality, and particularly Judaism.
item.dc:creator: JOHN WILLIAMS

item.title: Nonfiction: Power and Punishment: Two New Books About Race and Crime
item.media:description: Prisoners at prayer at Gadsden County Jail, Quincy, Fla.
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad for The New York Times
item.description: James Forman Jr.’s “Locking Up Our Own” and Chris Hayes’s “A Colony in a Nation” compel readers to wrestle with very tough questions about racism, inequality and punishment.
item.dc:creator: KHALIL GIBRAN MUHAMMAD
item.category: Locking Up Our Own: Crime and Punishment in Black America (Book)

item.title: The Enthusiast: In Praise of Agatha Christie’s Accidental Sleuths
item.media:description: The mystery writer Agatha Christie at her home in Wallingford, England, in 1956.
item.media:credit: Hubert de Segonzac/Paris Match, via Getty Images
item.description: The doyenne of mysteries is best known for Poirot and Miss Marple. But her less famous detectives are the ones who keep this reader coming back.
item.dc:creator: RADHIKA JONES

item.title: Nonfiction: People Have Limited Knowledge. What’s the Remedy? Nobody Knows
item.description: In a complex world, people fail to realize just how ignorant they are. In “The Knowledge Illusion,” Steven Sloman and Philip Fernbach tell them.
item.dc:creator: YUVAL HARARI
item.category: The Knowledge Illusion: Why We Never Think Alone (Book)

item.title: Fiction: A Debut Calls a Ferrante-Style Female Friendship to the Fore
item.media:description: Julie Buntin
item.description: In Julie Buntin’s first novel, “Marlena,” the past and present overlap in a portrait of an electric friendship cut short.
item.dc:creator: DEBORAH SHAPIRO

item.title: Noted: Charlamagne Tha God Puts His Straight Talk in a Book
item.media:description: Charlamagne Tha God in the iHeartRadio offices in TriBeCa, where he is a co-host of “The Breakfast Club.”
item.media:credit: Andrew White for The New York Times
item.description: In “Black Privilege,” the radio and TV host recommends honesty as a form of self-empowerment.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN KURUTZ

item.title: Maureen Chiquet’s Move From Chanel to Self-Empowerment
item.media:description: Maureen Chiquet, the former global chief executive of Chanel, has a book deal and a new career path.
item.media:credit: Nathan Bajar for The New York Times
item.description: Fired from her job with the French fashion brand, Ms. Chiquet emerged with a new career plan and a new relationship.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA FRIEDMAN
item.category: Beyond the Label: Women, Leadership, and Success on Our Own Terms (Book)

item.title: Open Book: Murder, He Wrote
item.description: The recently reissued “Killings” collects pieces of Calvin Trillin’s true-crime writing for The New Yorker.
item.dc:creator: JOHN WILLIAMS

item.title: Alec Baldwin Settles Scores in New Memoir
item.media:description: Alec Baldwin
item.description: “Nevertheless” debuts at No. 5 on the hardcover nonfiction best-seller list.
item.dc:creator: PARUL SEHGAL

item.title: Bana al-Abed, Girl Whose Tweets Told of Aleppo’s Horrors, Gets Book Deal
item.media:description: Bana al-Abed and her mother, Fatemah, in Ankara, Turkey, in December.
item.description: The 7-year-old, now a refugee in Turkey, hopes her book, to be published by Simon & Schuster, will “bring peace to children all over the world.”
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: The Book Review Podcast: Power and Punishment
item.description: Chris Hayes talks about “A Colony in a Nation,” and Jason Zinoman discusses “Letterman: The Last Giant of Late Night.”
item.category: Letterman: The Last Giant of Late Night (Book)

item.title: Fiction: Gilded Cage: A Wealthy White Family in East Africa Faces an Islamist Uprising
item.description: In Jean McNeil’s novel “The Dhow House,” East Africa’s violent unrest threatens a privileged white family.
item.dc:creator: MELANIE FINN

item.title: Fiction: Robert Louis Stevenson Never Wrote This Novel. So Brian Doyle Did It for Him.
item.media:description: Robert Louis Stevenson at work.
item.description: Brian Doyle’s “The Adventures of John Carson in Several Quarters of the World” is an affectionate homage to the author of “Treasure Island” anchored in the months he spent living in San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: JENNY DAVIDSON
item.category: The Adventures of John Carson in Several Quarters of the World: A Novel of Robert Louis Stevenson (Book)

item.title: Nonfiction: A New Biography of Martin Luther Reveals the Life Beyond the Theses
item.media:description: Luther in a 1523 engraving.
item.description: In “Martin Luther,” Lyndal Roper explores the theologian’s life and improbable career.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW PETTEGREE

item.title: Letters to the Editor
item.description: Readers respond to Fran Lebowitz, Angus Deaton’s review “The Crisis of the Middle-Class Constitution” and more.

item.title: Nonfiction: The South (and the West) through Joan Didion’s Eyes
item.media:description: Joan Didion with her Corvette, 1971.
item.description: Through excerpts from her notebooks, Joan Didion recounts a monthlong road trip through the Gulf states during the 1970s in “South and West.”
item.dc:creator: LAILA LALAMI
item.category: South and West: From a Notebook (Book)

item.title: Nonfiction: Have a Banana. On Second Thought, Don’t.
item.media:description: The 19th-century potato blight in Ireland.
item.description: In “Never Out of Season,” Robert Dunn looks at how modern societies make themselves vulnerable to crop devastation.
item.dc:creator: RAJ PATEL
item.category: Never Out of Season: How Having the Food We Want When We Want It Threatens Our Food Supply and Our Future (Book)

item.title: Fiction: In This Tale of Online Intimacy, the Only Wise Characters Are Luddites
item.description: “Sympathy,” Olivia Sudjic’s debut novel about social media obsession and digital heartbreak, tracks the dark side of online companionship.
item.dc:creator: KAITLIN PHILLIPS

item.title: Crime: Silos, Sulfur and Stolen Identities: The Best of New Crime Fiction
item.description: This week’s crime column features two familiar sleuths, V.I. Warshawski and Lincoln Rhyme, as well as a disgraced reporter and a Victorian detective.
item.dc:creator: MARILYN STASIO

item.title: Paperback Row
item.description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB

item.title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
item.description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.

item.title: By the Book: Lesley Stahl: By the Book
item.media:description: Lesley Stahl
item.description: The journalist and author of “Becoming Grandma” says Ann Patchett’s “Bel Canto” reminded her of Gabriel García Márquez, a high compliment: “My all-time favorite book . . . is ‘Love in the Time of Cholera.’”

item.title: Bookends: Which Force is More Harmful to the Arts: Elitism or Populism?
item.media:description: Adam Kirsch
item.description: Adam Kirsch and Liesl Schillinger discuss the art yielded by populist and elite mind-sets.
item.dc:creator: ADAM KIRSCH and LIESL SCHILLINGER

item.title: Patricia McKissack, Prolific Author Who Championed Black Heroes, Dies at 72
item.media:description: Patricia McKissack and her husband, Fredrick, shared a “missionary zeal” to write books about black personalities “where there hadn’t been any before,” their son said.
item.media:credit: John L. White/St. Louis Post-Dispatch, via Associated Press
item.description: Ms. McKissack looked for children’s literature about black history and saw a void. So she filled it, writing more than 100 books.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Q. & A.: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: 21 Great Buildings Throughout History
item.description: In “Fallen Glory,” James Crawford provides a tour from the Tower of Babel to the World Trade Center.
item.dc:creator: JOHN WILLIAMS
item.category: Fallen Glory: The Lives and Deaths of History's Greatest Buildings (Book)

item.title: James Baldwin’s Archive, Long Hidden, Comes (Mostly) Into View
item.media:description: A page from “The Amen Corner,” a three-act play by James Baldwin, part of his personal papers that are now at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture.
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.description: The Schomburg Center in Harlem has bought this author’s rich archive. But the private letters admirers have longed to read will largely remain under seal.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER SCHUESSLER
item.category: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture

item.title: Books of The Times: The Osage Indians Struck It Rich, Then Paid the Price
item.media:description: The Osage Indian sisters, from left, Minnie, Anna and Mollie Burkhart.
item.description: “Killers of the Flower Moon,” David Grann’s new book, recalls how Indians were killed by whites who coveted the oil under their land in 1920s Oklahoma.
item.dc:creator: DWIGHT GARNER
item.category: Killers of the Flower Moon: The Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI (Book)

item.title: Bill Cosby’s Books Join ‘Most Challenged’ List
item.media:description: One of the titles in Bill Cosby’s “Little Bill” book series.
item.description: There have been calls for the removal of Mr. Cosby’s children’s book series from schools and libraries.
item.dc:creator: GRAHAM BOWLEY

item.title: A Second Bite of the Wonka Bar: Reimagining ‘Charlie’ for Broadway
item.media:description: A golden ticket: Jake Ryan Flynn as Charlie Bucket in “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” on Broadway.
item.description: The New York musical version of “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” required a new director, a new cast, a partial rewrite and old favorite songs.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON

item.title: Nonfiction: A New Rule Book for the Great Game
item.media:description: Anne-Marie Slaughter
item.description: In “The Chessboard and the Web,” Anne-Marie Slaughter calls on foreign-policy makers to radically update their vision of global order.
item.dc:creator: SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.category: The Chessboard and the Web: Strategies of Connection in a Networked World (Book)

item.title: The Shortlist: Food Marks Milestones in These Culinary Collections
item.description: Three food-oriented memoirs take readers as far as the Pacific Northwest and Iran, and as near as a New York matriarch’s kitchen.
item.dc:creator: MAX WATMAN
item.category: The Temporary Bride: A Memoir of Love and Food in Iran (Book)
A Year Right Here: Adventures With Food and Family in the Great Nearby (Book)
My Mother's Kitchen: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner, and the Meaning of Life (Book)

item.title: Young Adult: New Y.A. Novels Tackle Crime and Its Consequences
item.description: A roundup of new young adult fiction includes stories of a thief seeking justice, a skeleton revealing a city’s shameful past and a gorilla spinning tales.
item.dc:creator: JEN DOLL
